ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to apply different writing styles to varying genres, depending on the audience and publication type. This class helped me think through essays from a first to final draft with in-depth feedback from my professor and classmates. Overall, I gained greater insight on my strengths and weaknesses as a writer, and I feel capable of identifying those weaker areas by myself now.
I learned to be a clearer and more direct writer.
I learned so much about a diverse array of writing styles and techniques and the kaleidoscopic array of literary ways to view a single event.
It was a great workshop in Urban planning and writing simultaneously. I found it interesting to examine and learn about a subject while learning how to write about it.
I became a much better writer during this course. I learned how to develop my own writing strategies while reading some of the best examples of theme-based nonfiction writing.
In this class, I relearned how to write, academically. I learned to close read, and learned how to write alternative forms of non-fiction.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the class workshops. It was enjoyable and instructive to give and receive feedback, and it also brought the class together. I was able to get to know my classmates as people and writers throughout the semester. Give or take a couple readings, I enjoyed our syllabus and was grateful to be introduced to new authors.
I would have liked a greater diversity of readings. We read almost exclusively pieces about New York in the first two weeks.

I loved this class. You'll get a lot of different type of assignments and it'll be fun to see how you can make each work and which you like best. I think the course would be much stronger with more short field trip/creative nonfiction components, especially because we live in a city. I LOVED how there was an entire course about cities: as a much-loved interest of mine, it was SO FUN to get to talk about them every week and really get into the grits of cities.
Strengths- Great readings, great speakers, and good class discussion

This course is very engaging. The material is interesting and great examples of what the course is helping you to develop in regards to writing. Sometimes the readings felt redundant or unnecessarily too many, but the professor is very open to changing the well-crafted syllabus.

This class was well-suited support wise. I came in with a relatively dated and poor understanding of writing skills, and was given lots of feedback to improve my work. The class fostered great conversation, and I came to enjoy the company of my professor and classmates.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone who writes, no matter their preferred writing genre. I think it's natural that students will prefer some units over others, but I often learned the most about my strengths and weaknesses as a writer when I was pushed outside of my comfort zone.
Yes! If you like creative nonfiction, then this course is great. The workload is very manageable, and the lack of a final paper due after reading week is amazing.
YES!!! It was a lot of fun and you'll learn a lot about who you are as a writer through trying so many different writing techniques.
Absolutely! Pam is great and if you are interested at all in cities this is the class for you.
Yes, this course has such an interesting topic that can truly be relevant to each student. At the same time, this topic allows for a breadth of knowledge about cities to be explored.
I would. This was one of the best courses I've taken at Yale.
